revealing opportunities to build new services and improve operations

Think about my needs

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

getting to know their own datasets

everyone's open data

body: What should you look for when assessing the sustainability of an open dataset?
displayTitle: What should I look for when assessing sustainability?
title: Q: What should I look for when assessing sustainability?
instruction: Choose three of the options below and select 'Submit'

_items.text: The data's publishing history
How much it costs
Who is already using  the data
What format the data is in
Who is funding the data's release

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Looking for the publishing history, who is using the data and how it is paid for are all key questions to ask when determining the sustainability of the dataset.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Looking for the publishing history, who is using the data and how it is paid for are all key questions to ask when determining the sustainability of the dataset

body: What is the benefit of having open transport data?
title: Q: Changing society and public policy
instruction: Choose an answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: It saves people time and improves access
It makes trains faster
It makes tickets cheaper

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open transport data saves commuters time, makes journeys more accessible and streamlines access for tourists.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open transport data saves commuters time, makes journeys more accessible and streamlines access for tourists.

body:
Open data has the power to help grow economies, transform societies and protect the environment.

Open data can help governments grow economies, improve service delivery and save on costs.

Open data can benefit society by improving the ways we move, the ways we work and the ways we govern.

Open data can help save lives and help us better understand the world in which we live.

Ready to get involved? In the next module, we explore how to engage in an open data initiative.

Next module

Main menu
title: Summary

body:
Open data has the potential to help grow economies, transform societies and protect the environment.

In this module, we explore how governments, businesses and individuals are using open data to create new value.

In this module we’ll explore:

  • Innovation and growth in businesses
  • Opportunities for governments
  • Impact on society and public policy
  • Benefits for culture and the environment.
title: Unlocking value from open data

body:
Implementing an open data initiative often involves cultural and institutional change.

Engaging with civil society, businesses and governments is an important part of the process.

As the open data community matures, many initiatives are taking user needs into account early on in planning their activities.

Open data requires us to think differently about the way the market for data functions.

In the next module, we'll look at simplifying open data licences.

Next module

Main menu
title: Summary

body: ODI International Development Manager Liz Carolan shares five characteristics of successful open data initiatives.
displayTitle: Engaging in open data initiatives - in 2 minutes
title: Engaging in open data initiatives - in 2 minutes
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

body:
Implementing an open data initiative often involves cultural and institutional change.

Opening data goes far beyond putting data on a website under an open licence. Applying the technology is the easy part – bringing about cultural change can be much harder.
title: Open data: agent of change.

body:
When searching for sustainable sources of open data, it is important that they are relevant, up to date and accessible.

A sustainable programme is one that continues to release data regularly, with at least the same or improving quality and quantity.

Using simple indicators listed above, it is possible to identify sustainable sources of open data that can be used in your future work.

In the next module, we explore how open data platforms can simplify the process of publishing and using data.

Next module

Main menu
title: Summary

body: ODI Startup Programme Manager Ulrich Atz explains the importance of sustainability for open data and why it matters to users. He also talks through some of the key indicators that an open data initiative is built to last.
displayTitle: Making open data sustainable – in 2 minutes
title: Making open data sustainable – in 2 minutes
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

body: There are two helpful things to remember when thinking about sustainable open data, can you remember them?
displayTitle: Are you ready for sustainable open data?
title: Are you ready for sustainable open data?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body: Active leadership and engagement helps foster successful open data initiatives and bring about positive change.
title: Leadership and engagement
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Active leadership
_items.body:
As an open data programme is launched, it is common for those driving it to meet some resistance from within their organisations.

Active support from senior figures can help to encourage institutional buy-in.

_items.title: Active engagement
_items.body:
Engagement with civil society, business and government are key aspects of any open data initiative.

Successful initiatives tend to start with an open dialogue between open data publishers and consumers.

This dialogue is important for both parties to understand the demand for data and opportunities to draw out its benefits.

_items.title: Finding space to innovate
_items.body:
Strong leadership and active engagement with key stakeholders is key to any successful initiative.

Active leadership delivers a 'push' from the organisation, active dialogue creates a 'pull' from data users.

Open data leadership and dialogue unlock innovation opportunities by connecting problems with potential solutions.

body: Applying technology is the easy part. Implementing culture change can be much harder.
title: Culture change for new markets
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Identifying new markets
_items.body:
The traditional market for open data, where governments publish data for others to consume, has changed.

Governments, businesses and society are all now both suppliers and consumers of open data.

_items.title: Culture change
_items.body:
Adopting open data will often require a change in the way an institution operates.

People driving initiatives need to spend time developing a shared vision, overcoming barriers and building coalitions for change.

Consumers should be empowered to engage with open data as a core part of their data infrastructure.

_items.title: Planning for change
_items.body:
Ways to handle and plan for culture change are becoming clearer.

Governments, organisations and individuals should have free access to key education, tools and guides that help plan for the future.

Pilots and practical initiatives play important roles in understanding the impact of open data and the change process. There are tools and guides to help you assess and plan for change, such as the ODI's Open Data Pathway.
Take me to ODI Open Data Pathway

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body: ODI Trainer Ben Cave examines how businesses and governments are unlocking value from open data and the positive impacts this has on the economy, society and the environment.
displayTitle: Unlocking value from open data – in 3 minutes
title: Unlocking value from open data – in 3 minutes
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

body: There are lots of valuable examples of open data initiatives bringing social, economic and environmental benefits. Are you ready to join the open data movement?
displayTitle: Are you ready to unlock value from open data?
title: Are you ready to unlock value from open data?

body:
A sustainable open dataset is supported by:

  • Secure funding to cover the cost of updates
  • Active support of publishers to prioritise updates
  • Wide reuse by others to demonstrate the value
title: What makes open data sustainable?

body: Open data awareness is no longer a luxury for public servants, it is now...
title: Q: Opportunities for government
instruction: Choose an answer, then click Submit

_items.text: a little more important than it used to be
something that should be researched more
a crucial part of modern service delivery

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data is crucial part of modern service delivery in order to support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data is crucial part of modern service delivery in order to support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones.

body: A sustainable release combines secure funding, active support and wide reuse. These traits are not always obvious when you first find a dataset. Ask yourself the following to help spot good sources:
title: Looking for clues
instruction: Click the headings to learn more.

_items.title: What is the source?
_items.body:
Ask yourself who has released the data and how much confidence you have in their commitment to continue to update it.

One of the most important indicators of sustainability is how confident you feel in the organisation that collects it.

If the data is from government, might an election or a change in priority affect its open release?

_items.title: Who is funding the release?
_items.body:
Data available at no cost might seem ideal, but it's important to ask yourself how a publisher is funding its sustained release.

Ask yourself whether the data is being released due to transparency pressures, or whether there is a wider beneficial use driving demand.

Try to find out whether there is a specific short-term programme funding the data's availability or whether the release is part of the organisation's core strategy.

_items.title: What does the licence say?
_items.body:
Licences can also offer clues about data's sustainability.

When looking at a licence, ask yourself what the text might indicate about the dataset's future and the publisher's confidence in it? Does it contain a commitment to update it regularly?

Remember that without a licence, data is not truly open. The licence gives you certainty that data can be freely used and shared.

_items.title: Who is already using the data?
_items.body:
The more widely a dataset is used, the more pressure there is for it to be sustained.

Ask yourself who else is using this dataset and for what purposes.

Try to find out whether the dataset is used internally by the publisher.

Both aspects indicate whether the publisher cares about the dataset and is under external pressure not to remove access to it, or change it for their own purposes.

_items.title: What is the publishing history?
_items.body:
Assessing open data's sustainability ultimately depends on how much trust you place in its publisher.

Ask yourself how long the dataset has been published for. A long history of updates is a good sign, but beware external factors such as project length or term in office. A key indicator of a sustainable initiative is one that outlives these external factors.

_items.title: How can I contribute?
_items.body:
Using a dataset yourself will help drive its demand and influence its sustainability.

Think about joining any communities of practice that exist around the dataset.

Try to find out whether the publisher plays an active role in these communities and whether they act upon feedback to improve their services.

Ask yourself what value you can demonstrate that will enhance the sustainability that is ensured by the data publisher.

body: What factors help make an open dataset sustainable?
displayTitle: Making sense of sustainability in open data
title: Making sense of sustainability in open data
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Secure funding for open data
_items.body:
Just because a dataset can be freely used does not mean there is no cost to collecting or releasing the data. Funding can be secured by:

  • Charging for access or enhanced services
  • Funding from another source who supports open data publication
  • Demonstrating the ongoing value of open data to the organisation

_items.title: Active support for open data
_items.body:
Making open data sustainable for an organisation usually requires the backing of its management, to make it a priority, and the support of staff responsible for maintaining quality.

Active support is most commonly achieved by a company committing to maintaining open data as part of its daily operations.

_items.title: Wide reuse of open data
_items.body:
Sustainable reuse is achieved when the services created with that data become critical to the success of the publisher’s business. The Berlin transport system Verkehrsverbund Berlin-Brandenburg's datasets are used by millions when they access transport apps like Citymapper. These apps drive usage of VBB services and, as such, VBB have a commitment in their digital strategy to regularly update the data.
Take me to Citymapper Berlin

body: Why should I care whether or not the open data I work with is sustainable?
title: Why does sustainability matter?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Solid foundations
_items.body:
Sustainability is not just good for the users. The publisher also benefits from a sustainable open data programme by:

  • Enhancing the trust of the community in the publisher’s organisation.
  • Supporting the creation of new products and services.
  • Simplifying the publishers reuse of their own data.

_items.title: Enhances trust
_items.body: Sustainable open data allows a large community to build and analyse data in order to draw their own conclusions, often in support of a publisher's view.

_items.title: Builds business connections
_items.body: Sustained open data has the power to unlock new customer channels, enabling other businesses to build on a publisher's data. In many cases these businesses provide direct benefits back to the publisher.

_items.title: Improves data usability
_items.body: One of the most frequent reusers of a publisher's data may well be the publisher. Why separate the public release of data from the internal data usage?

body: Which of these does not influence the sustainability of an open dataset?
title: Q: What influences sustainability?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Secure funding
Large filesize
Active support
Wide reuse

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

File size is not a factor in data's sustainability. What matter most are a secure source of funding, the active support of the publisher and wide reuse to generate value from the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

File size is not a factor in data's sustainability. What matter most are a secure source of funding, the active support of the publisher and wide reuse to generate value from the data

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]
The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]
The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
The most successful open data initiatives share similar characteristics. Understanding successful approaches can help unlock the value of open data.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • Open data as an agent of change
  • Leadership and engagement
  • Supply and demand
  • Culture change for new markets
title: Open data: agent of change

body:
Open data must be relevant, up to date and accessible in order to be useful.

A sustainable open data programme is one that continues to release data regularly with at least the same or improving quality and quantity.

In this module we'll explore the following:

  • How to make sense of sustainability
  • Why sustainability matters to you
  • What to look for in sustainable open datasets
displayTitle: Why should we worry about sustainability?
title: Why should we worry about sustainability?

body:
Open data is supporting innovation and growth by revealing opportunities for businesses large and small to build new services, identify savings and improve operations.

In Paris, café owners are using open data to attract tourists to the city's most affordable coffees, while in Iceland farmers are using open data about the quality of their lambs to attract new customers.

Open data stimulates innovation by removing barriers to access, use and shareability of data.

Data literacy is a core skill for businesses looking to take advantage of the opportunities open data offers to create new value and improve operations.
title: Innovation and growth in businesses

body: The public sector benefits from open data initiatives in many ways:
title: Opportunities for government
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Supporting growing economies
_items.body:
To support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones, governments need to publish key datasets.

Governments also need to support data infrastructure that connects data with those who use it.

In return, governments are reaping the benefits of a growing data economy, such as in Finland where SMEs with access to open data grew 15% faster than those without.

Take me to the Finnish case study

_items.title: Improved service delivery
_items.body:
Governments need to balance the demands of growing populations with the need to tackle small-scale, local issues.

The availability of detailed open data is essential to improving delivery of services at the local level.

There are over 17,000 schools in Ukraine, the Open School Project is the only service that provides detailed information about all of them. Open data allows the Open School Project to scale easily while providing a valuable service to citizens.
Take me to the Open School Project

Examples of other local services include Fix my Street who allow citizens to report maintenance issues in their neighbourhood to the local councils.
Take me to Fix my Street Norway

_items.title: Cost savings
_items.body:
Open data allows governments to make savings in key areas such as healthcare, education and utilities.

In the UK, open data helped reveal £200 million of savings in the health service.

In Ukraine, Prozorro is reporting over 800 million of savings for due to its open contracting procurement reforms. Additionally they have published all the results as open data via an interactive dashboard.
Take me to the Prozorro dashboard

In France, energy data is being used to drive more efficient energy generation practices.
Show me the France energy data.

body: Open data is unlocking new social value and enabling better targeted public policies.
title: Changing societies and public policy
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Improving the way we move
_items.body:
Open data has the power to revolutionise the way we travel.

All over the world open transport data allows companies like Citymapper and Google to give people accurate transport information. This not only helps people understand and use complex transport systems, it also decreases the number of people in cars and increases revenue for public transport systems.

Open transport data is estimated to provide time savings for commuters in London of between £15 and £58m a year and that was in 2012.
Take me to the case study

Within the Dutch transport industry, open data is helping a growing number of small companies to develop new services.

A new Dutch app, winner of the prestigious Apps4Europe competition, helps disabled people to book travel assistance for their journeys using open data.

Open transport data saves commuters time, makes journeys more accessible and helps tourists to travel in unfamiliar cities.

_items.title: Improving the way we work
_items.body:
Open data is changing the way we work.

Open data reduces the time needed to find information and allows professionals to focus more of their time on productive activities.

For example YouControl is using open data on corporations to help businesses identify the best partners for different projects. This saves time manually searching for the best partners while identifying those who may not be known.
Take me to YouControl

_items.title: Improving the way we govern
_items.body:
Open data is becoming a key source of evidence for governments in the policymaking process.

Open data is also making the development of public policy more transparent and supporting dialogue between governments and citizens.

Open data on key issues such as immigration, trade and budget cuts can be used to inform important policy decisions.

In Ukraine, the Better Regulation Delivery Office uses open data to ensure that the Ministry of Health is using up to date regulations that match international standards. This helps develop the ministry provide an innovative service that allows physicians to use evidence-based medicine instead of the authority-based medicine.
Take me to the Better Regulation Delivery Office

body: Open data is helping people target initiatives for cultural and environmental benefits.
title: Benefiting culture and the environment
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Environment
_items.body:
Open data helps farmers to improve yields and support a growing population without the need to destroy valuable habitats.

In the Ukraine Agri Eye uses open data to build an analytical system for remote vegetation and soil sensing for farmers. They claim that up to a 30% saving can be achieved through efficient land usage.
Take me to Agri Eye

Plantwise are collecting open data to produce valuable information packs for farmers about plant health and threats from diseases.
Take me to Plantwise

_items.title: Saving lives
_items.body:
Open data is helping to save lives. Open geographic data and aid statistics are being used by humanitarian groups to deliver targeted supplies in disaster zones.

Open mapping data helped disaster response teams target aid delivery during the 2010 Haiti earthquake.
Show me the Haiti Open Street Map.

Open data was also used for responses to the Philippines typhoon in 2014.

Open data is also being used to track the Ebola virus outbreak in West Africa in 2015.
Show me the Ebola open data jam.

_items.title: Culture
_items.body:
Open data is connecting people with important cultural issues and helping to shape a more informed debate around them.

OpenGLAM is helping to capture the heritage and cultural memories of groups in Germany, Switzerland and Finland.
Take me to OpenGLAM.

The Open Data Institute is leading a global Data as Culture programme, with artists in residence re-examining the fundamental ways in which data is perceived.
Take me to ODI Data as Culture

body: When examining an open data initiative, consider the following:
title: Supply and demand
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Your approach
_items.body:
Many open data publishers have taken the approach of building a portal, publishing the data they have, and hoping it is what consumers want or need.

As open data literacy grows, people are starting to think first about the needs of data consumers and shape their initiatives accordingly.

A staged approach helps to ensure that an organisation can walk before it tries to run, and achieves change in small, noticeable steps, rather than setting ambitious goals that are hard to meet.

_items.title: Who wants your data?
_items.body:
There is little point in publishing open data if there is no one prepared or motivated to create new value from it.

It is often best to focus on demand that currently exists.

Use existing consumer dialogues, opinion surveys or ‘vox pops’ to see where the demand is, and follow it.

Think about problems that already exist and how your data relates to them. Offer your data as a tool to help build solutions.

_items.title: Who will use and support your data?
_items.body:
A successful open data initiative has an engaged community who actively use the data, with access to resources that support them.

A strong community of open data reusers has a sense of ownership over the data. This ownership should cover both the data and the outputs generated from it.

It is important for publishers and consumers to fully understand each others’ perspectives.

A good example of a strong open data community is the Open Street Map project.
Take me to the Open Street Map project

body: Open data becomes usable when...
title: Q: What is quality open data?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: it is imported into our system
a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it has an open licence
the government publishes it

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it is made available under an open licence.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it is made available under an open licence.

body: There are three legal considerations as part of the standards for publishing open data, one of which is...
title: Q: Legal considerations
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: not to break the licensing law
to publish any type of data
to protect sensitive information such as personal data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. Protect sensitive information like personal data, preserve the rights of data owners and promote correct use of the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. Protect sensitive information like personal data, preserve the rights of data owners and promote correct use of the data

body: There are three technical considerations as part of the standards for publishing open data, one of which is...
title: Q: Technical considerations
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: what format the open data is published in
whether it can be used on a computer
whether it takes up much bandwidth

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

body: The Open Data Institute advocates the use of its own quality marque known as...
title: Q: Marques of quality
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: the ODI big green tick
the ODI stamp of approval
Open Data Certificates

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The Open Data Institute has developed Open Data Certificates that include practical and social requirements alongside in-depth legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The Open Data Institute has developed Open Data Certificates that include practical and social requirements alongside in-depth legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing open data.

body:
Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it.

Both of these require the permission of the publisher, granted via an open licence. However, the open licence alone is not sufficient to guarantee the usability of data. Simply putting a file on a website with an open licence does not constitute open data.

It is unlikely that users will be able to properly engage with unusable data to derive insights and demonstrate benefits.

In the next module, we compare open data initiatives and look at the key performance indicators of successful ones.

Next module

Main menu
title: Summary

body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant explains what quality data is, how to recognise it and which quality marques consumers of open data should look for.
displayTitle: Assessing open data quality – in 2 minutes
title: Assessing open data quality – in 2 minutes
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

body:
Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it.

Users of open data need the permission of its publisher, granted by an open licence. But the open licence alone is not enough to guarantee the usability of data.

It is unlikely that people will be able to engage with data to derive insights and demonstrate benefits unless it is usable.
title: What is open data quality?

body:
Marques of quality provide users with confidence about the quality and usability of open data.

There are two key indicators of open data quality:
title: Marques of quality
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: 5 Stars
_items.body:
The '5 Stars of linked open data' include the basic legal definition and technical excellence of the published data.

The 5 Stars were developed by inventor of the Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, in 2001. The 5 Stars make recommendations for the format and structure of the data.

You can learn more about the 5 Stars in modules 10 and 13 of this course.

_items.title: ODI Open Data Certificates
_items.body:
The Open Data Institute's Open Data Certificates are practical, social, legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing or using open data.

The certificates act as a self-assessment questionnaire for publishers, and in some cases users, to assess and benchmark the full usability of a dataset.
Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificates site

body:
Assessing how usable open data is cannot be done quickly.

There are a number of community-based standards and quality marques that can help you to assess how usable data is.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What makes data usable
  • How standards help increase the usability of data
  • Marques of quality
title: What makes quality open data

body: Can you recall the practical, technical, legal and social requirements for an open dataset to be useful?
displayTitle: Are you ready for quality open data?
title: Are you ready for quality open data?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body: Community-driven standards define the legal, practical, technical and social requirements for an open dataset to be useful.
title: Community-driven standards
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered.

You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data.
  • Preserve the rights of data owners.
  • Promote correct use of the data.

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website.
  • Update the data regularly if it changes.
  • Commit to continue to make the data available.

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • The format in which the data is published.
  • The structure of the data.
  • The channels through which the data is available.

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels.
  • Discussion groups and forums.
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data.

body:
The last decade (up to 2017) has seen growing support for greater government transparency and evidence-based policy making for the benefit of every citizen. Having a set of agreed and supported principals is of critical importance to maintain the focus on the benefit that open data can bring. 

This module introduces the Open Data Charter and the key principals it outlines for open data.

This module looks at:

  • Why have a charter?
  • The key principals of the Open Data Charter
  • How the Open Data Charter has been used in Ukraine
displayTitle: The key principals of the Open Data Charter
title: The key principals of the Open Data Charter

body:
Open data and transparency provide equal opportunity for all businesses and citizens to question, engage and innovate with government data. Having a set of agreed and supported principals is of critical importance to maintain the focus on the benefit that open data can bring. 

The Open Data Charter helps maintain focus in a number of key ways:

  • Helps advocate for open data at a high political level
  • Helps spread lessons from those who are implementing open data projects and connect them with each other
  • Works with different sectors to turn high-level open data principles into practical action
  • Drives momentum for the open data movement by supporting governments to commit publicly to the charter principles
title: Why have a charter?

body: The Open Data Charter consists of six principals. Explore the first four below:
title: Charter principals (1-4)

_items.title: 1. Open by default
_items.body:
If your government is constantly making decisions on which data to open, they are closed by default. 

'Open by default' is the principal that everything should be open automatically. A case must be made to close the data. There must be decisions and clearly defined policies on what to close (e.g. well-defined sensitive or personal data). 

With 'open by default' civil servants are encouraged to automatically open up data and information resources to the public. 

The charter encourages a culture and reward system based upon being open.

_items.title: 2. Timely and Comprehensive
_items.body:
Open data and information should be made available without undue delay and be as complete as possible. 

Ideally, data should be made available in its original, unmodified form, and link data to any relevant guidance, documentation, visualisations, or analyses.

If anonymising or aggregating data to remove personal or sensitive data, this though be done in such a way as to preserve as much value of releasing the dataset as possible. 

Data users should be consulted and feedback channels made available to help improve and accelerate engagement with the data.

_items.title: 3. Accessible and Usable
_items.body:
Data should be made available without bureaucratic or administrative barriers and without cost.

Links to data should be provided on portals and relevant websites that give people confidence that they are accessing authoritative data. 

Data should be available in widely used formats to ensure the widest range of users are able to access and use the data.

_items.title: 4. Comparable and Interoperable
_items.body:
Data should be presented in structured and standardised formats to support interoperability, traceability and effective reuse.

Data users should have access to sufficient information to understand the source, strengths, weaknesses and analytical limitations of the data.

To help with this, data should be fully described with all accompanying documentation data written in clear, plain language.

body: The remaining two principals of the charter focus on why the data is being made open. Discover more below:
title: Principals 5 and 6

_items.title: 5. For Improved Governance and Citizen Engagement
_items.body:
Open data strengthens the governance of and trust in public institutions, reinforces governments’ obligation to respect the rule of law and provides a transparent and accountable foundation to improve decision-making and enhance the provision of public services.

Open by default is a responsibility to proactively and automatically give citizens access to data and information. Additionally, citizens' rights to freedom of expression will be respected, even to those using open data to identify corruption.
_items.strapline: 5. For Improved Governance and Citizen Engagement

_items.title: 6. For Inclusive Development and Innovation
_items.body:
Open data is, by nature, an equitable resource that empowers all people by allowing them to access data regardless of who they are or where they live.

Open data can stimulate creativity and innovation, as well as help meet global challenges such as poverty, hunger, climate change and inequality.

Businesses and citizens alike should be encouraged and supported to use open data, both for commercial gain and collective benefit. 

Open data can empower the future generation of innovators, providing benefits to the whole of society, much like the Web has today.

body:
Ukraine joined the Open Data Charter in October 2016, a decision that helps demonstrate action following the mass protests for government transparency in 2014.

Joining the Open Data Charter has helped to drive the open data agenda within the Ukrainian government. This engagement with the international community has strengthened the political will of those at the top of government to support the work of the State Agency for E-government. 

The charter forms the basis of the roadmap for open data development in Ukraine. The six principles have helped define the 21 units and 59 tasks that determine what data will be disclosed in 2017.
displayTitle: How the Open Data Charter has been used in Ukraine
title: How the Open Data Charter has been used in Ukraine

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

displayTitle: Are you ready to adopt the Open Data Charter?
title: Are you ready to adopt the Open Data Charter?

body: You have been tasked to a collect a new set of data, how do you decide whether it should be available as open data?
displayTitle: Principles of the open data charter
title: Principles of the open data charter

_items.text: You establish the demand for it from users
You submit a case for it being open to the open data project
There is no need to, it should be open by default. A case should have to be made to close it

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Open by default is the principal that everything should be open automatically. A case must be made to close the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open by default is the principal that everything should be open automatically. A case must be made to close the data.

body: Why is the Open Data Charter important to the global open data movement?
title: Why have a charter?

_items.text: The Open Data Charter supports and holds governments to their open data commitments
The Open Data Charter funds open data initiatives
The Open Data Charter helps governments to protect their data resources

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The Open Data Charter supports governments and holds them to their open data commitments. It drives momentum for the open data movement by supporting governments to commit publicly to the charter principles.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The Open Data Charter supports governments and holds them to their open data commitments. It drives momentum for the open data movement by supporting governments to commit publicly to the charter principles.

body: Which of the following are principles of the charter?
displayTitle: Principles of the Open Data Charter
title: Principles of the Open Data Charter

_items.text: Open data should published as soon as possible
Open data should be free from bureaucratic and administrative restrictions
Data should be open by defalt
Open data should be fully described with links to detailed, easy-to-read documentation
Open data should have a cost associated with it
Open data should be made available only to those who provide credentials

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The principles of the Open Data Charter state that open data should be open by default, published in a timely manner, free from bureaucratic and administrative restrictions and provided alongside easy-to-read documentation.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The principles of the Open Data Charter state that open data should be open by default, published in a timely manner, free from bureaucratic and administrative restrictions and provided alongside easy-to-read documentation.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body:
The last decade (up to 2017) has seen growing support for greater government transparency and evidence-based policy making for the benefit of every citizen. However, not everyone is behind this agenda. Having a set of agreed and supported principals is of critical importance to maintain the focus on the benefit that open data can bring. 

The Open Data Charter helps maintain focus in a number of key ways and sets out six key principals that governments can sign up to. 

To date (May 2017) 17 governments all over the world – including Ukraine – have signed up to the Open Data Charter and you can find out more about the charter here.
title: Summary

body:
В Україні термін відкритих даних  регламентовано Законом України про доступ до публічної інформації. Цей Закон визначає поняття відкритих даних (стаття 10.1) та умови їх використання (стаття 10.2).

Публічна інформація у формі відкритих даних - це публічна інформація у форматі, що дозволяє її автоматизоване оброблення електронними засобами, вільний та безоплатний доступ до неї, а також її подальше використання. Публічна інформація у формі відкритих даних є дозволеною для її подальшого вільного використання та поширення - Будь-яка особа може вільно копіювати, публікувати, поширювати, використовувати, у тому числі в комерційних цілях, у поєднанні з іншою інформацією або шляхом включення до складу власного продукту, публічну інформацію у формі відкритих даних з обов’язковим посиланням на джерело отримання такої інформації.
title: Що таке відкриті дані?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body:
Відкриті дані – це дані, які є доступними і вільними у використанні та розповсюдженні будь-якою особою. Влада, бізнес та окремі громадяни можуть використовувати відкриті дані з метою одержання певних соціальних, економічних  та екологічних переваг. 

У цьому модулі ми проаналізуємо: 

  • Що таке відкриті дані?
  • Що таке дані?
  • Що робить дані відкритими?
  • Навіщо нам відкриті дані?
title: Що таке відкриті дані?

body: Доктор Девід Террент, тренер Інституту відкритих даних, пояснює що таке відкриті дані, що робить їх відкритими та навіщо вони нам.
title: 2 хвилини знайомства з відкритими даними
instruction: Щоб ввімкнути/вимкнути субтитри, натисніть кнопку «сс» у нижньому правому кутку вікна.

body: Без даних – немає інформації, без інформації – немає нових знань.
displayTitle: Від вихідного матеріалу до нової інформації та знань
title: Від вихідного матеріалу до нової інформації та знань
instruction: Натисніть стрілку вперед, щоб побачити більше.

_items.title: Дані
_items.body:
Дані - це сировина, з якої можна отримати інформацію та знання.

Просто уявіть, що такі дані, як місцезнаходження, фото, описи, відгуки та ціни, можуть стати вашим головним помічником у, наприклад,  плануванні відпустки.

_items.title: Інформація
_items.body:
Дані стають інформацією, коли їм надають контекст.

Виходячи з попереднього прикладу, місцезнаходження, фото, описи та ціни допомагають зібрати інформацію щодо туристичного об’єкта. 

Збір та представлення даних допомагають сформувати інформацію.

_items.title: Знання
_items.body:
Знання – це те, що ми отримуємо з інформації і персоналізуємо для власних потреб. 

Набуття знань – це процес перетворення інформації у вибір. 

Враховуючи попередній приклад, якщо ви знатимете, що жоден з членів вашої родини не любить парки розваг, ви зможете вирішити, яке місце точно не підходить для відпочинку вашої сім’ї, а яке вас влаштує.

body:
Дані є відкритими, якщо вони є доступними і вільними у використанні та розповсюдженні будь-якою особою.

Є декілька простих речей, які потрібно враховувати при визначенні факту відкритості:
title: Що робить дані відкритими?
instruction: Натисніть на заголовки, щоб дізнатися більше

_items.title: Обмеження
_items.body:
Якщо дані є відкритими, то не може бути жодних обмежень їхнього використання у будь-який спосіб.

Будь-яка особа може вільно використовувати, змінювати, об’єднувати і розділяти дані, навіть у комерційних цілях.

_items.title: Вартість
_items.body:
Відкриті дані мають бути безкоштовними у використанні, але це не означає, що доступ до них також має бути безкоштовним. Досить часто встановлюється плата за створення, збереження та оприлюднення даних.

Теоретично, будь-яка платня за доступ до відкритих даних має бути встановлена на рівні не більшому ніж допустима вартість відновлення блоку даних, що запитується.

Для багатьох наборів даних вартість такого відновлення є незначною.

Постійна платня може передбачатися для оперативних даних та великих обсягів даних з метою надійного обслуговування.

_items.title: Повторне використання
_items.body:
Після отримання даних користувач може вільно їх використовувати, повторно використовувати і перерозподіляти, навіть у комерційних цілях. 

Відкриті дані вимірюються тим, для чого вони використовуються, а не тим, яким чином вони стають доступними. 

Такі аспекти, як формат, структура і можливість машинного зчитування, роблять дані більш практичними, і завжди повинні враховуватися. 

Проте все це не робить дані більш відкритими.

body: Відкриті дані різнобічно сприяють роботі влади, бізнесу і громадянського суспільства.
title: Навіщо нам відкриті дані?
instruction: Натисніть стрілку вперед, щоб побачити більше.

_items.title: Реформування влади
_items.body:
Відкриті дані можуть допомогти зробити владу більш прозорою. Вони можуть стати доказом того, що державні кошти витрачаються, а політики впроваджуються належним чином. 

Наприклад, пошуково-аналітична система.007 допомагає контролювати, яким чином витрачаються державні кошти та ідентифікувати будь-які зловживання, пов’язані з цим. Ця онлайн-система забезпечує доступ до відкритих даних та візуалізацію, що сприяє більш простому використанню та розумінню конкретної інформації з великих наборів даних. 

Перейти на .007

Сервіс Rada4you допомагає перевірити як голосують депутати Львівської міської ради в дуже простому і зручному форматі .

Перейти на Rada4you  

Можливо найбільш трансформаційним кроком України є створення системи Prozorro та зведення процесу контрактування в публічних закупівлях до міжнародних стандартів.Від початку роботи системи Prozorro , конкурентність на ринку зросла на 15% від 45% підрядників, які не брали участь в тендерах раніше. Таке збільшення конкуренції також посприяло економії 10% витрат.  

 Перейти на сайт Prozorro

_items.title: Створюючи нові бізнес-можливості
_items.body:
Відкриті дані надають можливості бізнесу створювати нові зв’язки з клієнтами

Opendatabot – це сервіс, який на основі відкритих даних дає можливість користувачам здійснювати моніторинг реєстраційних даних українських компаній та судового реєстру. Використовуючи цю інформацію,  можна вибрати найкращого контрагента і захиститися від рейдерських захоплень.

Перейти на сайт Opendatabot

Подібним чином сервіс YouControl використовує  реєстраційні дані компаній, щоб допомогти бізнесу знайти найкращих контрагентів для різних проектів.

Перейти на сайт YouControl

_items.title: Захищаючи нашу планету
_items.body:
Beб став ключовою складовою нашої інфраструктури і відкриті дані будуть розвиватися на основі цього.

Відкриті дані про погоду можуть завчасно попередити про екологічну катастрофу.

Перейти на сайт Центру новин ООН

Відкриті дані також допомагають споживачам зрозуміти їх особистий вплив на навколишнє середовище і яких заходів необхідно вжити, щоб поліпшити його.

Перейти до Звіту «Кращий вибір – краща угода» (Better Choices Better Deals report)

Український агростартап Agri Eye використовує відкриті дані для створення аналітичної системи дистанційного  зондування рослинності та ґрунтів для фермерів. Автори стверджують, що можна зекономити 30% витрат шляхом ефективного використання землі.

Перейти на сайт Agri Eye

displayTitle: Чи готові ви до відкритих даних?
title: Чи готові ви до відкритих даних?

title: П: Що робить дані відкритими?
instruction: Oберіть правильну відповідь і натисніть «відповісти»

_items.text: Не передбачають обмежень в їх використанні

Вибірково доступні за окрему плату

body:
Відкриті дані – це дані, які є доступними і вільними у використанні та розповсюджені будь-ким.

Відкриті дані є базовою складовою цифрової ери, але на відміну від вугілля, деревини чи алмазів, їх може використовувати одночасно будь-хто.

Будь-які обмеження у використанні відкритих даних будуть зменшувати їх потенціал для створення нової цінності.

Відкриті дані різнобічно сприяють роботі влади, бізнесу і кожного громадянина окремо. Вони можуть допомогти поліпшити послуги, розвинути економіку та захистити нашу планету.

У наступному модулі ми дізнаємося як отримати користь від відкритих даних.

Наступний модуль

Головне меню
title: Summary
